title: Basic Problem Solving
description: Learn how to solve simple issues and mistakes on your own.

children.value: Issues, mistakes and bugs can happen even to the best programmer. You can develop a basic set of steps to potentially identify and resolve those issues without the help of others. Problems solved on your own can teach you many things and also feel rewarding. However, if you are stuck without being able to fix the problems by yourself, there is no shame in asking others for help.
This page focuses mostly on functionality which is provided by IntelliJ (and many other IDEs) such as Logging and how to use the Debugger.

The most basic but also fastest tool to identify problems is the console. Values can be printed there at "run-time" which can inform the developer about the current state of the code and makes it easy to analyze changes and potential mistakes.
implementing entry point class of the mod, a
is used by default, to print the desired output to the console.
Whenever you need to know a value for something at a specific point in the code, use this
// Values are used in a String to provide more information

window for the console is missing, you can open a new one in the toolbar at the top (

Keep in mind that this will also be printed if the mod is used in any other environment. This is completely optional, but I like to create a custom
method and use that, instead of the
itself to prevent printing data, which is only needed in a development environment.
// prevent usage if the Instance is not run in a development environment
// customize that message however you want...

in front of the line. The Search function

can be used to highlight it, making it easier to spot the problem. Missing assets, such as the Purple & Black placeholder when a texture is missing, also print their errors in the console and mention their missing files. You can also use the Search function here and look for the asset name in question.
Missing assets in a mod called "Acanthus Pocket"

A more "sophisticated" way of debugging is the usage of Breakpoints in an IDE. As their name suggests, they are used to halt the executed code at specific locations and make it possible to inspect and modify the state of the software with a variety of tools.
When working with Breakpoints, the Instance needs to be executed using the
Use the green bug icon to start the software in the Debug mode

Let's use a custom Item as an example again. The Item is supposed to increase its efficiency level, whenever it has been used. But whenever this happens all the remaining enchantments get removed. How can this issue be resolved?
Place a Breakpoint by clicking right next to the line number. You can place more than one at once if needed.

Then let the instance execute this part of the code. In this case, the custom Item needs to be used on a Block. The Instance should freeze and in IntelliJ a yellow arrow right next to the Breakpoint appears. This indicates at which point the Debugger is currently. In the
window the controls can be used to move the current execution point using the blue arrow icons. This way the code can be processed step by step.
The "Step over" function is the most common one so try to get used to its Keybind
If you are done with the current inspection you can press the
button at the left side of the
window. This will un-freeze the Minecraft instance and further testing can be done.

Currently, loaded values and objects are listed on the right side of this window, while a complete Stacktrace is on the left side. You can also hover, with the Mouse Cursor, over the values in the code. If they are in scope and are still loaded a window will show their specific values too.
Not loaded Integer vs. loaded Integer
object we can see that the enchantments are stored as NBT values. The
method removes all SubNbt values with the "Enchantments" key.
To avoid that, only the specific enchantment needs to be removed. This can be done using the
// Get a list of the itemStack's enchantments
// Keep only enchantments which aren't EFFICIENCY
// collect the entries of the stream for the final itemStack's enchantments Map
// put the changed enchantments Map (without the efficiency) back on the itemStack
// add the efficiency enchantment back with the new level
Probably the most roundabout way of increasing an enchantment level...

Sometimes it is necessary to only halt the code when certain conditions are met. Create a basic Breakpoint and right-click it to open the Breakpoint's settings. In there, you can use boolean statements for the condition.
It is possible to make limited changes to the code, while a Minecraft instance is running. Method bodies can be rewritten at run-time using the
option. This way, the Minecraft instance doesn't need to be restarted again. This makes e.g. testing Screen element alignment and other feature balancing faster.
When the instance is running and changes to the code have been made, use
to reload the changes. This process is also known as "Hotswap". If the changes were applied to the current instance, a green notification will be shown.
Other changes can be reloaded in-game.
The mod is done, everything seems to run smoothly and you just shipped the
file to the users. But suddenly you get complaints about crashes and other problems when the users try to play on a multiplayer server. What went wrong?

This is most likely an issue with the client and server interaction. Things which run in single-player still can cause problems in a server environment. To test this you can repeat the steps from above in a server running on your (private) localhost.
Keep in mind that you will run a server and the clients at the same time. This may be taxing on your computer's performance.

Now the server won't try to authenticate the client accounts who are joining the server. The set-up of the server is finished. The
Gradle task is used to launch the server and the usual server files are located in the project's
folder. You can interact with the server by using the server console.
Some testing requires multiple clients to interact in a multiplayer environment. Edit the
run configuration by pressing the white arrow. And modify the options to run multiple instances of this profile at the same time.

Now you can launch your client profile as many times as you want and connect multiple clients to your server. To check out all the instances and their consoles for logging and other purposes, switch the consoles with the tabs at the top of the console window.
The console of a previously executed instance helps with finding the issues. They are exported into the log files, located in the Minecraft instance's
directory. The newest log is usually called
. Users can send this file, for further inspection, to the mod developer or host the file content on code-hosting websites.
In the development environment you can find the logs in the project's
folder and the crash reports in the
Join the community and ask for help!
